perturbation.original_text: 1.1 "Affiliate" shall mean any company or entity controlled by, controlling, or under common control with a party hereto and shall include any company more than 50% of whose voting stock or participating profit interest is owned or controlled, directly or indirectly, by a party, and any company which owns or controls, directly or indirectly, more than 50% of the voting stock of a party.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.1 "Affiliate" shall mean any company or entity associated with a party hereto and shall include any company whose stock is partially owned by a party.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of "Affiliate" specifies a control threshold (more than 50% ownership). The modified definition removes this threshold and introduces the vague term "associated with," creating uncertainty. This contradicts standard corporate law definitions of affiliate, which typically involve significant control.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of corporate law regarding affiliate definitions.

perturbation.original_text: 1.14 "Laws" shall mean all federal, state and local laws and regulations that apply to this Agreement including, without limitation, (i) the Bayh-Dole Act (ii) the TM TM TM Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C § 321 et seq.) (iii) the federal Anti-kickback Statute (42 U.S.C. § 1320a- 7b(b)) (iv) the Stark Law (42 U.S.C. § 1395nn) (v) the Anti-Inducement Law (42 U.S.C. § 1320a-7a(a)(5)) (vi) the civil False Claims Act (31 U.S.C. §§ 3729 et seq.) (vii) the administrative False Claims Law (42 U.S.C. § 1320a-7b(a)) (viii) the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (42 U.S.C. § 1320d et seq.), (ix) the exclusion laws (x) SSA § 1128 (42 U.S.C. § 1320a-7) (xi) Medicare (Title XVIII of the Social Security Act), (xii) Medicaid (Title XIX of the Social Security Act); (xiii) the Clinical Laboratory Improvements Act of 1988 (CLIA); and (xiv) data security, protection and privacy laws in the applicable jurisdictions.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.14 "Laws" shall mean rules and guidelines that the parties deem important.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition lists specific federal statutes and regulations, grounding the agreement in established legal frameworks. The modified definition replaces this with a subjective standard ("rules and guidelines that the parties deem important"), contradicting the legally binding nature of statutory law. This change eliminates any reference to federal statutes, such as HIPAA, the Stark Law, and the False Claims Act, thus misaligning the agreement with established legal requirements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Various federal and state laws, including HIPAA, Stark Law, False Claims Act.

perturbation.original_text: 5.3 Licenses and Certifications. Biocept and, to the extent applicable, Life Technologies shall have at all times during the Term, all necessary federal, state and local licenses, qualifications and certifications to operate a laboratory and perform their respective components of the Test(s), including, but not limited to, state laboratory licenses, CLIA certification, CAP (College of American Pathologists) certification, FDA registration, and any other licenses or certification required by state and/or federal law.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.3 Licenses and Certifications. Biocept and, to the extent applicable, Life Technologies will try to obtain necessary qualifications to perform the Test(s), including state laboratory licenses.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause mandates that both parties possess and maintain all required licenses and certifications, specifying examples like CLIA certification. The modified version weakens this obligation to a noncommittal 'try to obtain' and removes mentions of CLIA certification and FDA registration, thus significantly weakening the legal requirements. This contradicts the legal obligation to maintain specific certifications for laboratory operations.
